intro: Lathyrus bolanderi var. violaceus, commonly known as the violet-flowered grass vetch, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, climbing stems and small, violet to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. Its leaves are trifoliate, with small, oval-shaped leaflets, and it produces small, pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. This species is of interest to botanists due to its unique floral structure and ecological adaptations.
